data.title: No formatter option for space between colon and type in TypeScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Write a TypeScript interface definition omitting space between colon and type (e.g. `name:string`)
2. Autoformat
3. Note that a space was inserted between ":" and "string"
4. Open user preferences in order to change this behavior
5. Note that among the many `typescript.format.insertSpaceAfter*` options, none address this area of syntax.

I prefer to omit this conventional space in order to differentiate `{key: val}` from `{name:Type}`. It would be nice to have the option to autoformat without having to forgo this convention.

data.title: Incorrect warning about "vscode" property in package.json file
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.7.0-insiders - OS Version: MacOS Steps to Reproduce: 1. open an empty workspace 2. create a `package.json` file 3. add `name` and`version` property 4. add an empty `engines` property Nothing in this workspace is supposed to refer to vscode.

data.title: add `code --list-versions`
data.body:
Along with #14034, I want to be able to list the available versions for an extension by doing something like:

```
code --list-versions Ionide.Ionide-fsharp
```

I did some digging and it looks like you already have the code to get all of the versions for an extension here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/build/lib/extensions.ts

Example request:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/80104/19543326/86a0d216-962b-11e6-9f90-7ed2b09e678a.png)

And corresponding response:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/80104/19543348/a150d35e-962b-11e6-8f01-adf3f3ee5568.png)

data.title: Support installing specific versions of extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I would like to be able to easily install previous versions of extensions. For example, I want to be able to do this:

```
code --install-extension Ionide.Ionide-fsharp --version 2.7.0
```

I just reported a https://github.com/ionide/ionide-vscode-fsharp/issues/217 and I want to be able to troubleshoot by easily rolling back to the previous versions of the extension.

Today, it is possible to manually download and install as explained here:
https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/editor/extension-gallery

data.title: Missing Sublime command - Increase / Decrease font size

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) I found that VS Code is missing feature parity with Sublime Text. The feature is increasing and decreasing font size. 

This is what I see in Sublime Text. 

![increase_decrease_font_size](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19541790/f511dc08-961d-11e6-96e8-c1b35c751a2d.gif)

The keyboard shortcut for this in Sublime Text is <kbd>ctrl++</kbd> and <kbd>ctrl+-</kbd> on Windows / Linux. The shortcut on Mac is <kbd>cmd++</kbd> and <kbd>cmd+=</kbd> to increase font and <kbd>cmd+-<kbd> to decrease font. 

Note that this feature is closely related to, but not quite the same as zooming in and out.

data.title: Missing Sublime command - find and select all occurrences of a symbol
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) I found that VS Code is missing feature parity with Sublime Text. The feature is find and select all occurrences. 

This is what I see in Sublime Text. 

![find_and_select_all](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19541692/0867dede-961d-11e6-9b48-036ce8d762c5.gif)

As far as I can tell an equivalent feature does not exist in VS Code. 

The keyboard shortcut for this feature in Sublime Text is <kbd>alt+f3</kbd> on Windows / Linux and <kbd>ctrl+cmd+g</kbd> on Mac.

data.title: cpptools do not find definition of local variables
Missing Sublime command - Go to word

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) I found that VS Code is missing feature parity with Sublime Text. The feature is go to word. 

![goto_word](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19541623/7baea090-961c-11e6-929b-92fba7a52003.gif)

Default keyboard shortcut is <kbd>ctrl+j</kbd> on Windows. Sublime Text does not define a keyboard shortcut on Mac for this by default.

data.title: Incorrect inclusion of @types in a TypeScript project
data.body:
According to https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html, if `"compilerOptions"`.`"types"` is specified, only the types you specify will be included in compilation. VS Code weirdly and unpredictably ignores this - in my case, it uses typings from `@types/node` instead of the one I specified (webpack-env). Compilation itself passes with no errors.
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a Typescript project, install `@types/node` and `@types/webpack-env`
2. specify `"compilerOptions"`.`"types"` (e.g. `[ "webpack-env" ]`)
3. watch how your `require.ensure(...)` gets underlined

data.title: Double clicking panel sash makes the panel minimum size
data.body: This is a regression, it used to set it to the default size on double click.

data.title: after pausing, breakpoint is not hit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: 10.11.6
- Node Version: 5.2 through 6.8.1 (at least)

Steps to (maybe) Reproduce:
1. add some breakpoints to your app
2. launch

Normally, the breakpoints are triggered and execution stops. A yellow line appears on the screen where the code is stopped. Playback controls appear. Sometimes this will NOT work correctly--execution stops, playback controls appear but WITHOUT the yellow line. You can click Play/StepOver/StepInto which may or may not cause VSCode to stop correctly at the next breakpoint in the series.

The worst part is that it's unreproducible. The same breakpoints will work for hours and then stop working suddenly.

Steps to mitigate the problem:
1. Less likely to happen if you have MORE breakpoints, especially on any lines that return promises. 
2. Sometimes you can persuade VSCode to find the next breakpoint if you click StepInto two or three times and then press play

I wish I could add more details to this issue. It's affected me for months but I was hesitant to create an issue because of my lack of data. If this is a known problem please let me know and I'll contribute in any way I can to the discussion.

data.title: Enable line highlighting for read only editors
data.body: Fixes #14021

data.title: Read only mode does not highlight selected line
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: macOS

The editor component of VSCode does not highlight/outline the currently selected line when in read-only mode. The ability to highlight lines in read only mode is useful for a variety of reasons. For example in [sourcegraph](https://sourcegraph.com/github.com/Microsoft/vscode@master/-/blob/src/vs/platform/editor/common/editor.ts#L49) we use this to bring attention to specific lines when the UI navigates the user to a new cursor position after a jump-to-definition.  

Steps to Reproduce:

You can reproduce this within the Monaco playground
1. Open the [Monaco playground](https://microsoft.github.io/monaco-editor/playground.html) and instantiate a new read only editor. E.g.

```
monaco.editor.create(document.getElementById("container"), {
    value: "function hello() {\n\talert('Hello world!');\n}",
    language: "javascript",
    readOnly: true
});
```
1. Click on the editor to set the cursor position. The line containing the selected position is not outlined. Remove the read only flag and observe the difference in behavior.

data.title: Test: Horizontal layout
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1749
- [x] Windows @isidorn 
- [x] Linux @Tyriar 
- [x] Mac @rebornix  

You can now switch between vertical and horizontal layout for opened editors. Verify
- you can switch the layout from the View menu, command palette and "opened editors" view
- the choice of layout is persisted and restored for the current workspace
  - you can have multiple windows open with different layout choice
- the layout is reflected by the split-icon in the editor header and quick open
- all of the following features still work in both layouts
  - closing groups and opening new editor groups
  - resizing using the sashes
  - DND of editor groups
  - DND of editors by dragging tabs (only when tabs are enabled)
  - DND of editors from outside (e.g. explorer, native files explorer)
  - editors "snap" to minimized when sized small enough and you can jump through the minimized editors making the currently active one maximized
  - you can still use the Panel properly when horizontal layout is enabled
  - all works when tabs are enabled or disabled
- try to break the layout
  - make sidebar large enough that size for editors gets small and start to split editors and change layout
  - same for the panel

We introduced a new setting `workbench.editor.defaultSideBySideLayout` (we changed this to `workbench.editor.defaultEditorGroupLayout` for consistency with other commands and options in later builds, please be aware) that allows to change the default layout that should be used for new workspaces.
- Verify changing this setting picks up the layout when opening workspaces for the first time
- Verify this setting is also picked up when opening an empty workspace

data.title: Test: some view settings moved into settings.json
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13328
- [x] anyOS @octref 
- [x] anyOS @rebornix 

Some new settings got introduced that are now being toggled from the view menu:
- `workbench.sideBar.location` to control the position of the sidebar (left or right)
- `workbench.statusBar.visible` to control the visibility of the status bar

Verify that changing those from the view menu updates the settings file and changes to the UI are applied.

In addition: verify changing the window zoom level from the View menu now writes to `window.zoomLevel`.

data.title: Slow Search
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.0 (e52fb0bc87e6f5c8f144e172639891d8d8c9aa55, 2016-10-10T18:28:55.412Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.4.0
- Extensions: HookyQR.beautify-0.4.1, anseki.vscode-color-0.1.11, christian-kohler.path-intellisense-1.1.0, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint-1.0.8, donjayamanne.githistory-0.1.0, ms-vscode.js-atom-grammar-0.1.10, robertohuertasm.vscode-icons-3.0.5, seanmcbreen.Spell-0.8.6, streetsidesoftware.code-spell-checker-0.10.13, zhuangtongfa.Material-theme-1.0.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a large file system
2. Search across the system

I love this product, but the only downside of it (which can be prohibitive when doing certain types of work) is how slow the search is when searching across the file system. Not sure if its a plugin I have installed, but searching in Sublime Text is relatively speedy (for comparison), while searching through VS Code seems to take a long time and never complete the search.
